title: What will be the end-of-day closing value for the British pound against the U.S. dollar on 30 June 2017?
preds: Did Mark Carney have to open his mouth three days before the deadline? And later claim he was misunderstood?
Trending up, with an hour to go.
Well, where did that rally come from?

Post Mortem-I'm not sure how I could better on this one. I could follow markets better but the margin was so narrow and the change so late that I don't know that I what I could've seen that was better than the rest of the crowd.  I'm leaning towards this being bad luck.

Closed at 1.3007 on 29 June. 
Intra-day trading range so far on 30 June is 1.2983 to 1.3030.
The GBP value is presently $1.3. Expect downward correction tomorrow.
Just over $1.30 at time of writing

Closed at 1.2926 on 28 June, and now 1.2969 early on 29 June, up from 1.2723 on 26 June.  In the more than six months since this question opened, the rate has been at 1.30 or more for just four days, 19th to 22nd May just before the opinion polls began to show a swing away from Theresa May. Yet with less than two days to go it is heading for 1.30 again, threatening to ruin a lot of forecasters' scores!  It just goes to show the truth of the saying "trying to time the market is a fool's game". Despite knowing that, and repeatedly vowing not to tackle currency or commodity questions, I keep getting sucked back in.
Wow! Big moves the last two days cannot be ignored. What I thought was a 100% done deal a week ago is not any longer.
Carney's comments have pushe up to $1.29

In light of the government's deal with the DUP, the stability of the minority government seems a bit shaky. While I think it has fallen as much as it will, there is a chance that it could go further if headlines are made regarding Brexit negotiations and Britain's lack of bargaining power.

The £ has remained relatively stable against the dollar, although it has only broken the 1.30 mark once since September 2016.  Given the economic insecurity associated with the ongoing EU Exit negotiations, it is unlikely that it will not pass the 1.30 mark again.

It is a chance for 1.30-1.40.   There may be a slight steep rise.  Theresa May says she hopes that all the parties in Northern Ireland will "come together and reach agreement to re-establish a power-sharing executive" by the 29 June deadline

As we get closer and closer to the deadline, it has become clear that the regular magnitude of swings in the value of the Pound is not large enough to warrant any substantial likelihood that it's value with move above $1.30. And since a value less than 1.2 was hardly recorded in the aftermath of 2016's Brexit, we can't expect movement in that direction either. I overshoot the collective wisdom here and say there'sa 99% chance of the ratio remaining between 1.2 and 1.3
One week to go, would be hard for the pound to climb to 1.30 in a week.
Going 100 percent given how the pound has fallen since that disaster of an election, not that I'm still bitter about May ruining my score on this site by calling that election.
With the market down this is starting to look like a done deal below 1.30.
Don't want to be so far from consensus.
Fed will hike. Expect modest USD strength. BoE will stay on course, as I expect to hear on Thursday 15th June.

USD/GBP has been trading between 1.20 and 1.30 for the last several months, with the exchange rate touching just above 1.30 around May 20.  Recent surprise election results have depressed the value slightly, but it is trading around 1.27 as of 6/12/2017. Unexpected economic announcements or geopolitical events could cause the rate to go above 1.30 (more likely) or less than 1.20 (less likely) by the end of June.
Teresa May let me down, lol.

Shifting significantly toward the middle option as the pound has long a fair bit of value since the election (an event that really hurt my score on this site so I'm weirdly glad May lost it so badly). I don't see any causes for dramatic improvement the rest of the month.

http://www.bbc.com/news/business-40243736
still bopping up and down amid various forms of uncertainty, but staying in the $1.20-$1.30 range.  So far, so good.
Pressure on the pound after elections changed the political landscape in the UK
There will not be a full blown recovery in June, despite the election results. Mid rage prospects look positive, with a soft brexit more likely and thus offering a degree more stability.

The pound is quite cheap, for the most part of depriciaton is in the field of politics, real production and services have remained the same since Brexit began. In the near future it is expected upward adjustment. Fall from 1.71 to 1.27 (2014-2017 - brexit)
Europe has a stronger hand in the coming BREXIT negotiations. Despite softer BREXIT, it becomes harder to justify good prospects for the UK economy.

https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPUSD:CUR The pound was 1.30 or above between 19 and 22 May, when it seemed Theresa May would be re-elected with a hugely increased majority.  Since 30 September 2016 that was the only time the closing rate was 1.30 or above. At the other end, the pound has not been below 1.20 in the last five years, though at 1.2047 on 16 Jan 2017 it came close. One can never predict currency fluctuations, and a precipitous drop is always possible with a tricky coalition in the UK having to start Brexit negotiations in a bit over a week, but for now I think the rate will remain between 1.20 and 1.30

British Pound Remains Lower After U.K. Election Dulaney (2017) Jun 9, states that: The British pound posted its biggest daily loss in eight months on Friday, while the dollar surged after British Prime Minister Theresa May’s Conservative Party unexpectedly lost its majority in Parliament. The pound fell 1.7% against the dollar on Friday, to $1.2741, its biggest one-day percentage loss since October. The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the U.S. currency against 16 others, rose 0.3%, to 88.51. Mrs. May’s Conservative Party had been widely expected to maintain a majority in Thursday’s general election, though polls had shown the race tightening in recent days. On Friday, she resisted calls to resign and moved to form a new government. Analysts say the election outcome is a mixed bag for the British currency. While investors fear a hung parliament could usher in a fresh period of political uncertainty, the weakened position of the Conservative party could also reduce the likelihood of the “hard” Brexit scenario that investors had feared. “Markets will interpret this general election result as a rejection of Mrs. May’s tough stance in the upcoming negotiations with the EU and consequently view a ‘soft Brexit’ as more likely,” said analysts at Nomura (para. 1-5). Dulaney, C. (2017). British Pound Remains Lower After U.K. Election. The Wall Street Journal. Markets. Currencies. Foreign Exchange. Retrieved from
https://www.wsj.com/articles/british-pound-remains-lower-after-u-k-election-1497019667
Election result --- hung Parliament --- moved GBP to 1.27 region, and I don't see what else could decisively move it before deadline.
Tories debacle causes pound to plunge, $1.27 USD right now. https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/GBPUSD:CUR
Can't see much upside for the pound by June 30, but don't think it will slip below 1.20 either.
Election result increased probability of GBP staying below $1.30.

http://www.lemonde.fr/europe/article/2017/06/07/brexit-le-ralentissement-de-l-economie-britannique-commence-a-se-faire-sentir_5139902_3214.html
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-election-markets-idUSKBN18Z2UW?il=0
Still hovering in the $1.20-$1.30 range.  Probably not going anywhere despite the election result, unless the PM's impending deal with the DUP fails to impend.  Stay tuned.
well, the election didn't go as expected!

Hung parliament likely to exert additional uncertainty over the next few weeks. With formal Brexit negotiations about to start, hard to see factors that would push the rate above $1.30. Comey hearing didn't have much of an effect on USD.
Time is progressing and there is a hung parliament. revert to current consensus estimate

June British election leaves UK uncertain of its future. Investors hate uncertainty.
*Revised from 0-50-50-0 prediction earlier.
The unexpected vote, which was a vote against hard Brexit, increases the chance of a GBP recovery as the market reprices that likelihood.
Market reversing so changing my forecast back more in favor of below 1.30
Given the recent firming, I'm going to weight this as a rise above 1.30 after May wins the election. Will adjust in a few days, depending on how things play out.
I must admit I don't understand how the consensus can be so confident (0/0/67/33/0 as of this comment) when the exchange rate has been floating so near the 1.30 threshold for so long.
Currently 1.295, UK election big unknown at this stage
I know I changed my forecast just a few hours ago, but the GBP is up almost 0.5% and it is just below the 1.30 threshold and there is only about three weeks on the clock. Forgive the micro-managing.
Adjusting the likelihood of 1.20-1.30 slightly. Clock is running out on an upward move.
am essentially betting there is no big surprise until end of June.

Looking like the poll results showing Labour snapping on the heels of the Tories were somewhat of a false alarm. Both parties' strategies see Tories gaining on their majority. The bulk of UKIP supporters are going over to the Tories and Labour are having a hard time keeping hold of many seats in the heartland of their support. Ever since Brexit there has been considerable air in the Cable, so a Tory win (increase in majority) could let off some steam. That said, by the end of the month the familiar Brexit uncertainty could set back in.
https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-06-06/labour-said-to-privately-be-preparing-for-a-u-k-election-defeat

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-markets-idUSKBN18W029
Most likely GBP will stabilize quickly when the election is over, unless Labour wins.  That is widely regarded as improbable, which of course matters less recently than historically....
As time continues to run off the clock, adjusting my forecast slightly toward the $1.20-$1.30 range.
1.30 seems to be the ceiling already rejected once and we got only a month remaining
Adjusting from 0/2/53/44/1, as GBP hasn't broken 1.29 in about a week.

Bloomberg median consensus GBP/USD latest is: Q2’17 = 1.28; Q3’17 = 1.27; Q4’17 = 1.27; Q1’18 = 1.28 When you look at individual broker:
At or above 1.30 is estimated by Citi, Barclays, Nomura. 
Below is estimated by HSBC, JP, Lloyds, Credit Suisse, BAML, Wells Fargo. To my knowledge Credit Suisse, Barclays and JP are the most active banks in FICC (besides Deutsche).  Given broker consensus below 1.30 and support from Credit Suisse and JP, I lean more towards “More than 1.20 but less than 1.30”.
I am interested in British Pounds since I will probably make a big purchase

Sterling slips on election fears, downbeat China PMI weighs on stocks Saminather (2017) Wed May 31, | 11:28pm, states that: Sterling retreated on Thursday on fears that Prime Minister Theresa May could lose control of parliament in Britain's June 8 election, while conflicting signals on the health of China's manufacturing sector kept most Asian stock markets in check. Sterling GBP=D3 retreated 0.1 percent to $1.2877 after a YouGov poll showed May could be well short of the number of seats needed to form a government, raising the prospect of political turmoil just as formal Brexit talks begin. Other polls, however, show May winning a big majority (para. 1-3). Saminather, N. (2017.) Sterling slips on election fears, downbeat China PMI weighs on stocks. Reuters. Business News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/global-markets-idUSL3N1IY07O
Somehow in the last few days I had beeen thinking to myself that the question resolved on the last day of May, hence my quickly escalting certainty. Back to roughly where I was a few days ago.
Using a slightly bullish bias to the GBP (+2% one year expected gain) and 10% volatility. Modest rally since last forecast adjusts things upward slightly.

Corrected again in favor of below $1.30, reasons: Tightening race according to the polls, increased uncertainty will keep the exchange rate low until the election. At this stage, only a larger than expected Tory victory could be anticipated to boost the exchange rate as a reaction, but I see this as unlikely (<20% probability), and even in the case the Tories win by a larger than expected margin, I see no reason why it should rise above $1.30 when it did not trade at those levels when a large victory was anticipated from the polls.
Assuming +2% one year expected gain on GBP and 10% volatility. 1% drop yesterday adjusts things moderately.

The pound dropped on political risks - polls suddenly indicating a tightening race. However, there are reasons to believe this is a polling fluke (see https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-26/sterling-slips-as-poll-shows-tory-lead-narrows-after-bomb-attack, which also has a nice chart linking traders' expectations of the link between the election result and the pound). Nevertheless, unless the polls reverse quickly in favor of a large Tory victory, the pound is likely to remain below 1.30 until the election and then react to the election result. A smaller than expected Tory victory seems to be a decisive minus.

Reducing possibility of > 1.30 due to recent polls showing Labour catching up significantly on the Tories. Right now it looks like May might actually have a smaller majority than before and therefore her Brexit hand (the whole point of the snap elections) will be diminished.
Updating from 2/50/46/2 after sudden fall today to 1.27 - 1.28 territory. Can't find any news to explain it.
Fed signalling rate increase should increase value of $

The exchange rate is more driven by USD weakness at the moment. Despite the bleak economic outlook for the UK and  the recent attack, the FED's decision to re-consider rate hikes expected in June 2017 is driving the $ down.
Looking increasingly likely that the pound may break the barrier of $1.30

Adjusted slightly in favor of below $1.30, as the Tory lead has decreased in the polls. There is still a fair chance if Tories win by a large margin the rate will jump up, so keeping it still close to the 50:50 probability.

GBP is trending up and at $1.30 today. If this continues should be sitting in $1.30 to $1.40 range.
Allowing for tail risk either side:
(1) Odd result of UK election or Brexit negotiations getting off to a bad start
(2) Trump administration doing something odd that affects value of Dollar
UK election on 8th June 2017. May at 42% polling average. Assumption that May will win (market has priced this in). Hence, x-rate remains stable

It was over $1.30 today for a while, and has been rising for months.   During elections, everyone is promising the sun, moon and the stars, so hope & optimism are high, thus I think it will stay relatively high:  at around $1.30 or slightly above until June 8th.   After the election, however, reality will set in.  Brexit negotiations will be tough and there will have to be painful adjustments on both sides, but especially in the UK, so I think it will start to fall back below $1.30 after June 8th. However, I do not like forecasting strongly against the present reality, so I'm sitting on the fence.

Went above 1.30 today. Another factor is that elections create uncertainty and markets tend to strengthen after them, whatever the outcome (mostly). So after 8 June I would expect the pound to jump up a bit and for that to last until 30 June at least. (Not sure if British markets going up implies gbp going up though?)
Updating a little bit here now that the pound has gone above $1.30, if there was a ceiling it may be gone.
The chance to buy into the pound at its low is lost. A more protectionist attitude in the UK will actually make the currency stronger.

It will hover around the $1.30 mark for the rest of the summer. This is based on numerous forward curve predictions. Given brexit scenarios and other potential drivers, there is slight risk to the downside but very minimal to the upside of $1.39.

The UK pound value plummeted after the unespected (to many) outcome of the referendum on leaving the European Union. Although the referendum had no immediate, binding effectl. Events that followed, including triggering of article 20 of the Union treaty, which de facto started the process of leaving the EU, had a comparatively lower impact on the currency. This suggests that, under these circumstances, the market is mostly influenced by uncertainty than by the impact these events will have on the economy. If UK elections will bring a a government with more moderate views on thr leave process, the impact on the currency will be modets, as this wuold decrease uncretainty on negotiations. On the US side, I have no information that makes me think of a jump (upwards or downwards) of the US in the shirt term at the moment.
Today's BoE statement was perceived as dovish by markets and the pound is retreating. May be 1.30 will hold as a ceiling after all.
Starting with today's rate 1.2979, assuming 5% gain in the GBP in the next 12 months, 10.5% volatility. I am arriving at the 5% gain due to the current upward trend in the x-rate.

At the time of forecast, (7th May 2016), the exchange rate is just below the $1.30 mark, but on the rise. When it became clear that there will be a re-election, that resulted in a small upward jump in the exchange rate. Considering that Theresa May is leading the polls, I think she will win this vote of confidence in her policy, which means that at this stage there don't seem to be any indications why the exchange rate should experience any unexpected jumps but develop steadily.

The pound is just below 1.30. What is the balance of factors going forward? 
Factors that would support the pound between now and end-June:
 - The Tories' expected large election victory;
 - the local elections showed Tory gains against the SNP in Scotland. A repeat on June 8 should give Sturgeon a pause in her push for indyref2 , reducing a risk to the pound;
 - relatively good UK economic data. Factors working against the pound:
 -  short covering appears to be over (I read somewhere this week that the short position against the pound is at a multi-month low). 
 - The US Fed is very likely to raise rates in June (see the CME numbers); however, this seems already baked in the cake.   
 - a difficult start of the Brexit discussions - again, already here. Not much news is likely to break by end-June.

The general election will be held June 8. May is expected to strengthen her party's lead and give her a stronger hand in the Brexit negotiation. This will probably lead the pound to rise in value.  A Labour victory (however unlikely) may put some short-term uncertainty into the value of the pound, but probably wouldn't cause it to crash as it would lend the possibility that Brexit won't occur. On the eve of Brexit one pound cost $1.48. Since Brexit it hasn't been close to $1.40 (right around $1.29 now). A surprising labour victory could bring it near where it was after some uncertainty subsided, but it would probably take more than a month to see where it would go. Outside of the UK, It doesn't look like the fed is going to raise rates in the US, which would make the dollar keep rising. If Le Pen wins in France, that could make investors flee Europe (but they may move from the euro to the pound; the dollar didn't get very weak when Trump won the election, even though the US is weird). I doubt a Le Pen win would make the pound crash. I don't think the pound will go less than $1.20 (it has been close, but not there since Brexit), but it may hover right around $1.28/29. The best guess is to probably think it will be close to where it is, but following its slightly upward trend would push it above $1.30
Reflecting change in market pricing mainly. Secondary reason is passage of time, only 8 weeks to go and confirmation of Conservative party win at election will boost sterling.
The pound has been trending higher and while I still don't think it will break the 1.30 ceiling, this doesn't look impossible anymore.
The poind had been over sold and all the negative news was baked in at below $1.20. Post election and if the Tories win big, the pound should temporarily push through $1.30.

The pound has picked up a little against the dollar and euro. Some analysts give as a reason that they believe that the Brexit negotiations will produce a compromise between the UK and EU, but they might just be looking for any reason explain to the rise. Some have quoted:
http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-eu-trade-britain-idUKKBN17T1HN
A rational person might well take the view that a free trade deal will be agreed, after all its in the interest of both the EU and UK. However most economists would also say that it would have been in the interests of the UK to not have voted for Brexit, but the UK did vote for Brexit. Which I guess proves that decisions are not always rational. 
The longer it is before the UK arrives at a trade deal with the EU, the greater the risk of the UK hitting a downward Investment Spiral There is a considerable lag between good or bad news and its affect on business investment (probable about 18 months). If the bad news was the Brexit vote in June 2016, the effects on investment will arrive around the end of 2017, but the effects of the economy as a whole will only be starting in 2018. The lack of investment will be damaging to productivity, which will hit profits unless the pound falls.
http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/brexit-business-investment-weak-2017-bank-of-england-credit-conditions-a7681686.html
Even if a UK EU free trade deal is agreed it will probable not be before 2019, by then there will have been at least a year of low business investment and a successful free trade agreement in might not result in business investment actually taking place until 2020 and feeding through to the economy until 2021. That's quite a wait.
1.2906 Current consensus of 10.64% for the fourth bucket seems a bit low given we are 1 penny from reaching it. Meanwhile, the second bucket is over 12% and we are 9 cents from reaching it.
Incorporating a minimum possibility of pound upsides for U.K. elections in June
This will be highly dependent on the results of the French election, and will involve many different factors that it's still a bit early to fully flesh out.

Increasing upside after election announcement jump. The pound will likely continue to strengthen over coming weeks as a lot of the short positions will unravel, but after the initial response, I expect the pound to trend lower again. If a Tory landslide starts to look likely will have to re-evaluate again.
How will the election affect this?

The announcement by prime minister May to call for an election substantially increases the chances for a soft instead of a hard Brexit and in fact may even lead to a full or partial cancellation of it. The UK economy and the GBP will benefit from this and increase its strength vis-a-vis the dollar.

Today the pound is surging on short covering, and this may go on for a few days. However, T. May's expected large election victory would make a hard Brexit more likely, as she would not have to fear negative Parliamentary reactions to the final deal with the EU. Previously prospects for hard Brexit have driven the pound down. At some point, the market may realize that and reverse course, although not all the way to below 1.20, I think.
Time, and the rate has been pretty stable. Chaos is probably already baked in.

Sitting exactly in the middle of the  1.20/30 band at present it is likely to stay within this range. From a UK perspective it is unlikely we will see much clarity from Brexit negotiations that will materially alter the trajectory of the currency. If we see any news on this front it is likely to be negative but still unlikely. From a US perspective, there are a couple of reasons we could see some weakness in the $ however this still feels like an outside bet. One is Trump's recent comments about the strength of the $, the second is the unease in North Korea and how this could affect the USD. All in all I feel this is still unlikely however.

I am stating the obvious; the rate could change due to the dollar becoming more desirable or the pound becoming less desirable. 
The big factor that might affect the pound is the Brexit negotiations, but the market thinks it knows what is likely to happen with this between now and the end of June - the EU will presumably formally agree to the plan that Tusk has already outlined, talks on the status of citizens may have started by July but he does not expect anything to have been agreed and talks about things that would affect the value of the pound will not have started. 
It is more likely that something will happen that will affect the value of the dollar. It is considered likely that US interest rate may rise, which would tend to make the dollar more attractive, but the markets have probably already built that in to the dollar's current price (in fact the dollar might rise in anticipation and fall a little on it actually happening).   Looking at the exchange rates for the last 5 years it is very unusual for the rate to change by 10 cents in the 10 week period. Currently it seems that $1.20 is a point of resistance on the downside and $1.27 seems seems a point of resistance on the upside, so if no significant events happen during the period of this question it seems most probable that it will remain + or - 3 or 4 cents from today's rate.  
http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=GBP&to=USD&view=1Y
Combination of worry over Brexit while US increases rates combines to drive pound to 1.20.  However, 1.20 is likely the floor given the technical indicators.
Either basing or continuation of its downtrend.
http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=GBP&to=USD&view=1Y Delta of chart tends to not be more than +-10% in 3 month period, IT's near an all time low and things tend to regress to the mean.
1.25 today but in a chaotic world who knows?

Factors exercising upward pressure on the pound vs. the dollar:
 - UK inflation. If it keeps coming as so far, and barring some growth calamity, the BoE's next move would be to tighten, or so the markets think. (It may take a while, though). 
 - US monetary policy. At present, the markets assign some probability to the Fed tightening again in June. I think not, however - looks like economic activity has hit a soft patch (again). 
 - most market analysts believe the pound is still undervalued. Factors that may push the pound below 1.20 - (i) some very bad news on Brexit - unlikely: too early, and the EU's tough negotiating stance is already baked in market expectations; (ii) news around the Scottish indyref2 - again, even if a legally binding date is set, it will be way into the future to have a marked effect now; (iii) Le Pen winning in France - this would push the euro down, and perhaps the pound vs. the dollar, if the expectation is that the ensuing turmoil would hurt Britain. But a Le Pen win is still a small chance.
Not yet the time to panic. And hardly a time to feel robust toward the pound either, so it stays in its current trading range for near-term.

The US Fed will continue towards an expansionist setting, whilst the pace of increase may slow, the sentiment lends itself towards further strengthening of the USD. That combined with the triggering of article 50 should see sterling weaken further but not to the degree of a swing below 1.20.
Unrest and uncertainty surrounding US president Trump and the White House translates into divergent views and forecasts on the US economy.
Anticipate a further decline in the pound - there will be continued US economic growth, and additional Brexit fears.

The trend is downwards with a much stronger US economy than the state the UK economy is currently and the, overall, poor prospects it has with the coming (starting up of the) Brexit and the unknown implications for the financial sector and industry in particular. There are more factors pointing downwards than upwards. The strengthening of ties between the two countries could als tie their currencies stronger together though.
It is likely that US dollar will weak with incoherent US Govt. policies.

Just a guess, but the Brexit will take a long time and business will go on as usual for the next 2  years and the European economy is so inter-connected that there will be no ridiculous swings for a while.
GBP dropped a bit. Moving 7 points from middle bucket to 1.10 and 1.20
Using janky Bloomberg chart referred to in question description.
adjusting for the recent weakening of GBP
1. Pound stabilizing some. 2. As we get closer to June 30 the possibility of normal std div decreases chance of extremes. 3. Fed rate increase and BOE easy policy makes it easy to aim low

The simple fact is major trading currencies do not typically fluctuate in relative value very much over the short term. Volatility between the major currencies tends to be only a few cents or less either way in a normal day and even month. There was a sharp drop in the value of the pound after the Brexit referendum (see link) but since then the pound has stabilized between 1.2 and 1.3; that combined with the fact that starting the Brexit process should be priced in already means there would have to be a truly shocking shock to move the pound outside that band. http://www.exchangerates.org.uk/GBP-USD-exchange-rate-history.html
Rate hike by Fed to prop up the dollar, Brexit uncertainty to drive pound lower.

Pound could have further to slip. Most business people and finance execs are anti-Brexit and current FX rate could express that optimism. Plus the USD itself could strengthen anyway off the back of Trump spending plans, stronger US economy and higher interest rates.
Elites in Britain are trying their best to walk-back Brexit.  Giving them some chance of doing this, which is why stronger pound is somewhat favored over the current ratio of $1.25

Brexit is going to happen and value of the pound has had time to stabilize in the 1.2 - 1.3 range. If Article 50 is invoked in March it may have some impact but any long term trend will depend more on how the exit negotiations are going.
after brexit, and first numbers out of ONS, will give a boost of GBP and potential growth to economy.
Currently at 1.243. Last 4.5 months range is low 1.202 to high 1.297.

Most powerful reason of pound price is Brexit. And When Brexit was fixed, Pounds value declined. Last few month, Pound price is around 1.20-1.30. and Brexit can not happen until June. The problem is FOMC and Donald Trump. But FOMC wants to raise the rate, and Trump doesn`t want powerful dollar. In my opinion, it will be good balance for dollar. So Pound will be around 1.10-1.30.

I think base case must assume that public information is largely priced in at the current c.1.25 level given liquidity of market. Estimate volatility of 6% over time period (based on historic prices). Likely fat tails. However, big moves are very rare >1.40 and <1.10 would require +/-12% in around 4 months. Suspect risks weighted soemwhat to the downside.

Current price fully reflects brexit and also positive reaction to Trump's policies in the short term, which will drive up US interest rates but the overall trend is toward a strengthening $ which would give the most likely scale to be between 1,10 to 1,30 this is reflected in most bank forecasts. Any major change in $ could come from a shock to the system which I believe is more likely to be on negative side for the $ and likely to generate an overshoot hence why the more than 1.40 is more likely than 1.30-1,40

My analysis suggests that concerns over Brexit and it's impact on trade and the UK economy are way over-blown.  IMHO, the main driver for this panic is the media.  They have an incentive to write articles with emotive and exaggerated claims.  This drives clicks and revenue.  Who wants to read an article that nothing much is going to change?  People read this and expect the worst.  The truth is, macro events happen all the time and the sky doesn't fall in.  On top of that, inflation may cause the BoE to consider hiking.  For this reason I expect upward pressure on the GBP. The market has priced in a reasonably trajectory of Fed rate hikes.  Any slowing of the economy could result in the Fed slowing their rate.  I'd say this is neutral for USD, as all things being equal, and no significant news coming, that the USD would otherwise slowly appreciate. Given a reasonable volatility, it is reasonably unlikely the fall outside the 1.15 to 1.35 range.  It's currently 1.25.
it will greatly depend on the brexit negociations
Inflation is more likely in US than in Britain.

Brexit is a net negative for UK gdp and will pull sterling down; mid-term effects of actually triggering § 50 and leavong single market for good are NOT yet priced in fully, as many participants in the market share dilussional thinking of brexiteers. On the other hand Trump wants the dollar down, not up, and tries to talk it down.
Trump will do something stupid and the dollar will dive.
The fed will need to be more aggressive on interest rates than the UK.

I see GBP drift higher as positioning of the market is short in light of article 50 triggered while valuation is for a stronger pound. Economic data should hold up ok. A US border tax scenario is the rsik for stronger dollar
Leaving the euro suddenly costs a lot!

Analyzing a yearly chart (GBP/USD), the tendency is for the GBP to decrease, due to various conflicts with the brexit, and since its around 1.2-1.3 for now, I predict it will slightly drop more and its mostly likely for it to be between 1.1-1.2. However, there is a chance of a more drastic drop, and goes to less than 1.1. And a very low chance of maintaining 1.2-1.3.
Reference:http://www.xe.com/currencycharts/?from=GBP&to=USD

The Pound was staying in the ($1.20-$1.30) range for almost 5 months now. So best guess is that it stays in there. 
I started with a symmetric distribution but than I gave a little bias towards an increase, mainly because the chaos produced by Trump could make the Dollar fall, which would make the Pound rise in relative terms.

The Pound was staying in the ($1.20-$1.30) range for almost 5 months now. So best guess is that it stays in there.
I started with a symmetric distribution but than I gave a little bias towards an increase, mainly because the chaos produced by Trump could make the Dollar fall, which would make the Pound rise in relative terms.

#very naive estimate from volatility
daily_vola = 0.01 
remaining_days = 136
price_today = 1.2390
change = 1.+daily_vola*np.random.randn(remaining_days, 100000)
change_tot = np.product(change,axis=0) 
end_price = price_today*change_tot 
print sum(end_price<1.1)/float(len(end_price)) 
print sum(np.logical_and(end_price>1.1,end_price<1.2))/float(len(end_price)) 
print sum(np.logical_and(end_price>1.2,end_price<1.3))/float(len(end_price)) 
print sum(np.logical_and(end_price>1.3,end_price<1.4))/float(len(end_price)) 
print sum(end_price>1.4)/float(len(end_price))
